data.text: Contents
Introduction
In the event of a national fuel shortage Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) may need to implement special measures in order to maintain the organisations core functions
It is envisaged that the main obstacle to be overcome in the event of a fuel shortage is that of human resources, primarily staff getting to work.

The Department for Energy and Climate Control (DECC) has developed a contingencies plan in the event of a fuel shortage known as the National Emergency Plan-Fuel (NEP-F). Within this plan are emergency powers that can be implemented in the event of disruption to fuel supplies that enable the continuing supply to the emergency services and other utility organisations, some of whom supply the health service. In the event of a fuel disruption the MSE will ensure flexibility and be sensitive to issues surrounding problems with staff transport. The Trust in response, expect where possible, flexibility and support from its employees during any such crisis. The Trust's response to a disruption in fuel supply will be proportionate to the scale of the disruption.
In the event of a minor fuel disruption the Trust will make all efforts to advise staff of responsible fuel purchasing and fuel conservation as well as cascading central government messages to staff.

In the event of a major fuel disruption the government may introduce emergency powers and activate various schemes in order to both conserve fuel and ensure that priority services and infrastructure are maintained. Within these schemes are contingencies to evenly distribute certain amounts of fuel to the public and also to ensure that the emergency services are supplied with fuel to provide their services. In addition, certain activities within the Trust may need to be assessed and potentially scaled down in order to conserve fuel.

The continuation of emergency clinical services and the activity that supports these services are the core functions that need to be maintained by the Trust in the event of a fuel disruption. Therefore, any special measures implemented by the Trust need to assist in maintaining these core functions. In addition, if the Trust can implement measures that will assist in the conservation of fuel it will help contribute to the national response of the disruption.

Contingencies to supply key staff using their own vehicles in the course of their work may be implemented; however, there is no provision for fuel to be given to staff to get to work. This will need to be taken into account by staff when the amount of fuel allocated to them as members of the public is provided. Alternative arrangements for getting to work may need to be considered d and they may need to consider alternative arrangements for getting to work during a period of fuel shortage. The Trust will endeavour to maintain staffing levels to maximum capacity wherever possible by activating in-house procedures which may include shift changes to accommodate staff who can get into work via public transport (public transport will continue to be supplied with fuel in a fuel crisis), or car sharing with colleagues may need to be considered.
Scope

The purpose of this document is to formalise the actions to be taken in response to a real or potential fuel shortage and flexibly adjust. The response to a disruption to fuel supply will be in proportion to the scale of the disruption, principal aims being to:
Protect staff, patients and visitors from the effects of the disruption when
Possible.
Be prepared for the risks that have been identified.
Supply an understanding of the legal aspects of priority user schemes.
Give advice to staff with regard to the Maximum Purchase Scheme (MPS).
Develop and endorse a fuel reduction strategy which can be implemented during a shortage for the benefit of business continuity.
Support the continuity of the Trust's essential and critical services as far as possible.
Support the continuity of everyday services and activities as far as possible.
Promote the return to normal service at the earliest but feasible possible opportunity.
To provide a strategic overview of the of the implementation of an emergency plan for fuel;
To provide a framework for response and recovery in the event of a fuel emergency;
To maintain business continuity across all services in the event of a fuel emergency;
To ensure appropriate management and administration of the Temporary Logo Scheme.
Definitions

table_items.text: Department Business, Enterprise and Regulatory Reform
Department of Energy and Climate Change
Department of Health and Social Care
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response Committee
The Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response Committee is responsible for ensuring that plans are in place to:
Supporting the development and implementation of Emergency Planning and Resilience capabilities in preparation for an emergency situation
Ensuring a Business Impact Analysis is completed for their Care Group / Division and specific service areas as deemed necessary
Ensuring a Directorate Resilience Plan (including Emergency Planning and Business Continuity) is in place for their Care Group / Division, if required.
Chief Executive
The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that the MSE has in place effective arrangements to respond to an incident that has the potential to affect service provision
Deputy Chief Executive / Accountable Emergency Officer (AEO)

The Deputy Chief Executive is the designated Accountable Emergency Officer for Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response, who is responsible for ensuring that the MSE has a Major Incident Plan in place that will also link into the organisations arrangements for business continuity, that is built on the principles of risk assessment, co-operation with partners, emergency planning, communicating with the public and information sharing.

The role of the AEO, is to endorse assurance to the board that the organisation is meeting its obligations with respect to EPRR and relevant statutory obligations under the Civil Contingencies Act 2004 (CCA) and the Health and Social Care Act 2012. This will include assurance that the organisation has allocated appropriate resources to meet the requirements.

The AEO will ensure that the Board receives regular reports, at least annually, regarding EPRR including reports on exercises, training and testing undertaken by the Trust, and that appropriate resources are made available to allow the discharge of these responsibilities.
The Accountable Officer is responsible for receiving notification from NHS England / Improvements Area Teams declaring a disruption to fuel in the area and will:
Chair the Fuel Incident Team in order to coordinate the Trust's operational response in the event of a major fuel disruption.
Update the Managing Director and Site Leadership team
Ensure that information about the disruption to fuel supplies and mitigating actions is cascaded throughout the Trust
Deciding if and when, and in what form, command and control arrangements need to be initiated
Ensuring that calming measures are in place
Approving the number of Temporary Logos requested by each Division / service
Ensuring Directors are taking appropriate action to maintain continuity of service and the safety and well-being of service users and staff
Ensure that business continuity arrangements pay due and proper attention to potential fuel shortages and staff depletion
Will give advice on impending fuel shortages in conjunction with the Head of Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response
Will in consultation with other Directors and the Head of Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response consider whether the Trust should declare a Major Incident?
Director of Operations (Local Services)
Directors and Senior Managers are responsible for ensuring that:
Business Continuity plans are developed and in place for their areas and functions of responsibility.
Business Continuity plans are cascaded to staff who are given appropriate training.
Plans are tested and reviewed annually or sooner as appropriate
Head of Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response

Ensuring resilience in the supply chain by making sure that critical suppliers and service suppliers who may be affected by disruption to road fuel supply are identified and that these suppliers have robust business continuity arrangements in place that take account of disruption to fuel supplies
Ensuring the MSE travel plan as well as reducing overall demand to address cost, efficiency and environmental sustainability, also addresses resilience and emergency preparedness.
General Managers
Oversee the effective implementation of the fuel plan within their Divisions.
Ensure Divisional plans are established to implement action plans agreed by the Fuel Incident Team.
Responsible for implementation of the Emergency Services Scheme once activated.
Cascade Communications messages.
Ensure ward managers and heads of department have effective plans in place to manage staffing and activity during a fuel shortage in line with their business continuity plans.
Representation on the Fuel Incident Team
Head of Communications
Ensuring there is an effective cascade system for informing staff that there is disruption to fuel supplies and what the contingency measures are
Developing agreed pre-prepared information for the intranet (Hub) and website on mitigating procedures, responsible purchasing of fuel, fuel efficiency measures, staff safety etc.
Co-ordinate media correspondence.
Co-ordinate communications to trust staff.
Representation on the Fuel Incident Team
Estates and Facilities Manager
Will organise on request from the Fuel Incident Team accommodation for key staff during a disruption
Will maintain information on local accommodation that may be accessed by the Trust if required
Representation on the Fuel Incident Team
Service Unit Managers / Ward Managers / Heads of Departments
Ensure staff are aware of their responsibilities.
Manage flexibility within shift patterns and consider reducing the number of shifts worked (by increasing hours each shift).
Team leaders for inpatient units to consider early discharge to cater for possible reduced levels of staff.
Ensure arrangements are in place for maintaining continuity of services.
Implement action plans agreed by Emergency Planning Panel where relevant.
Identify staff who may work either at home or closer to home.
Brief staff of the situation, any new developments and Trust actions.
Staff
Prioritise journeys, avoiding unnecessary journeys and taking into consideration fuel needed to attend work.
Utilise other means of transport where possible such as public transport, car sharing, walking or cycling to work.
Where the staff member had inadequate fuel to make the journey to work they should make every attempt to attend work by other means.
If all means have been exhausted and the staff member is unable to attend work they should contact their line manager giving as much notice as possible before the planned shift.
Command and control

As a result of increased service pressures, or the implementation of the NEP-F, it may be necessary for the MSE to convene an Fuel Incident Teams (FIT) at level 2 chaired by the Directors of Operations or delegated deputy's. The fuel incident teams WILL convene at level  The overall aim of this group is to direct the MSE's operational response and provide situation reports to NHS England and the CCG.
This group may consist of:
Accountable Emergency Officer / Director of Operations (Local Services)
Director of Nursing
Deputy Director of Workforce & Operational Development
General Managers / Deputy General Manager
Head of Workforce
Head of Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response
Estates Operations Manager
Estates and Facilities Site Manager
Head of Communications
Local Security Managements Specialist
Head of Departments (as and when necessary)
The fuel incident team should commence planning and consider the following key actions:
Reduce the Trusts dependency on fuel;
Reduce fuel usage during a disruption;
Review the resilience of supply chains;
Review critical services that need to be maintained;
Reallocate resources to deliver key services
Ensure effective communication with staff, patients and suppliers.
Implement calming measures.

The team should also commence planning for the distribution of temporary logos in accordance with the rules of the scheme highlighted earlier in this plan and further detailed below. Once a distribution strategy has been agreed it will be communicated trust wide.

In a shortage that requires the implementation of the NEP-F it is highly likely that a Strategic Coordinating Group (SCG) will be formed. The Fuel Incident Team will provide any necessary situation reporting to the SCG during the period and ensure the implementation of any requested actions.
The Fuel Incident Team will convene in the Hospital Incident Control Room as identified in the hospital Major Incident Plan.
National trigger points

There are four levels of alert to a national fuel shortage. These are identified below. Included are the potential triggers that might cause an alert to be declared and some of the actions that can be expected from the Trust.
Trigger Levels
Road fuel plan / MSEPO-21145 / 1.0
Page  of
LEVEL 1 – WHITE Situation Normal
LEVEL 2 – BLACK
Potential Fuel Emergency
LEVEL 3 – AMBER Actual Fuel Emergency
LEVEL 4 – RED Severe Fuel Emergency

Lowest alert level when the situation is as normal. This period is used by organisations for testing and reviewing  the  NEP-F  and  business  continuity processes and for maintaining contacts between stakeholders.

Incident  occurs  with  the  potential  to  cause disruption  to  fuel  supplies.  A  higher  state  of preparedness is required and action may need to be taken to coordinate a precautionary emergency response, including increased monitoring.
Significant  disruption  to  fuel  supplies  requiring action  to  coordinate  the  emergency  response across government and industry.
Severe  disruption  to  fuel  supplies  requiring immediate  action  to  coordinate  the  emergency response  and  consequence  management  across government and industry.
Trust operational response

table_items.text: Review and test Trust emergency plan for fuel; Review business continuity processes for fuel disruptions; Consider whether mutual aid arrangements would be effective; Identify those critical users requiring use of the temporary logo scheme in accordance with current guidance.

Review business continuity arrangements and prioritise services to be maintained. Liaise with Local Resilience Forum (LRF) to confirm DFS sites are still valid. Notify LRF of those sub- contractors qualifying for the UFS (e.g. Boots pharmacy)

Activate Trust Fuel Incident Team; Implementation of Trust's business continuity arrangements; Activation of mutual aid agreements if appropriate; Internal communications and briefings to staff on principles of NEP-F and local procedures; Issue of temporary logo applications; Situation reports provided to NHS England; Community Impact Assessments carried out; Agreed LRF media strategy to be implemented.

Issue of temporary logos and guidance. Total numbers issued to be reported to LRF; Situation reports provided to LRF as required; Continued review of business continuity arrangements and reporting of transport issues; Review of temporary logo scheme, consideration for extension of issue subject to event duration and stock levels at Maximum Purchase Scheme Sites; Community Impact Assessments; Agreed LRF media strategy to be reviewed and revised as appropriate.

data.text: Minor fuel disruption

7.1.1 In the event of a minor disruption to the supply of fuel the Trust will communicate with staff advising them of responsible actions and passing any central messages. This will ensure that staff are prepared and also reinforce the message of responsible fuel purchasing which will prevent a minor disruption becoming significant.
7.1.2 The messages given to staff in this type of scenario would include:
Buying fuel normally and not panic buying is the responsible thing to do and will avoid creating problems that weren't already there
Drive sensibly to conserve fuel use as per guidance issued by the Government upon implementation of the NEP-F
If possible avoid using the car, use public transport, walk, cycle or car share where possible
Ensure that they prioritise car use to have enough fuel to get to and from work
if necessary and ensure if on-call, they have enough fuel to last them for that period
7.1.3 Messages need to be communicated sensibly avoiding the potential to cause panic. These messages can be coincided with any messages received centrally.
Major fuel disruption

7.2.1 In the event of a major fuel disruption the government may be forced to implement emergency powers under the Energy Act  In this incidence special measures may need to be put in place by the Trust in order to manage during the disruptions.

7.2.2 In the event of a severe fuel disruption it may be necessary for the Trust to suspend non-acute activity in order to ensure the core Emergency functions of the organisation are maintained. This suspension would be coordinated by the Chief Executive in collaboration with NHS England and the CCG.
Emergency powers
Maximum purchase scheme (MPS)

8.1.1 Under emergency powers the Government may issue a scheme to limit the public to 15 litres (approximately three gallons) of fuel per visit to a petrol station. This should be adequate for staff to be able to travel to and from work. Staff will need to cut down on journeys that are non-essential and should be encouraged to use their vehicles sensibly. Staff will be expected to conserve fuel as far as possible to ensure that they can get to and from work at all times.

8.1.2 This purchase limit may need to reduce further if the situation deteriorates. It is assumed that the average vehicle used for getting staff to work has a consumption rate of 25 miles per gallon across all fuel, driving and vehicle types, this gives an average 75 mile limit on a single fill up.
Emergency service scheme (ESS)

8.2.1  The priority use schemes for specified priority users would be introduced by the exercise of emergency powers under the Energy Act  The Emergency Services Scheme (ESS) will supply road fuel to logoed ‘blue light' service vehicles.
Temporary logo scheme (TLS)

8.3.1 A Temporary Logo Scheme would be introduced for drivers of non-logoed vehicles to enable the essential health, social-care and critical life-saving services provided by or on behalf of Local Authorities, Health Authorities and Local Responders to continue. The Temporary Logo scheme would be introduced
following the exercise of emergency powers under the Energy Act 1976.

8.3.2 It may be necessary to utilise this scheme in order to ensure key staff are available and to provide a service (e.g. community midwives Hospital at Home, Bridging Services and emergency on-call staff etc.) however these services should be assessed and scaled down where possible.

8.3.3 However, to avoid the risk of abuse the Trust must ensure that temporary logos are only given for those vehicles that are used in carrying out critical services, and which cannot gain access to fuel through any of the other schemes implemented.

8.3.4 Regular communication with the Local Resilience Forum (LRF) should be maintained to keep an up to date record of the Designated Filling Stations within the area. This information can then be disseminated as required to staff.
Criteria for temporary logos

8.4.1 Under the National Emergency Plan - Fuel it identifies those staff that would be eligible for a temporary logo as those staff who are conducting essential health, Social - Care, and life – saving services, this does not cover staff travelling to and from their place of work and is therefore designed for staff that provide care / emergency care in a community setting.

8.4.2 Under the National Emergency Plan - Fuel temporary logos will be issued to those staff that qualified under the scheme, these logos can be used to obtain fuel from the designated fuel stations within the county.
8.4.3 Certain staff are recognised such as General Practitioners, Midwifes, and Specialist Nurses who provide care to patients who are chronically ill or End of Life Care within a community setting.

8.4.4 The Trust at present runs a fleet of courier vehicles, in the event of a disruption to fuel these vehicles will be eligible under the temporary logo scheme as they would form an essential part of the Trusts business continuity arrangements.

8.4.5 In the event of such an emergency temporary logos being issued, this will be strictly managed by the MSE Head of Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response in order to mitigate the possibility of abuse, as under the National Plan – Fuel abuse of this scheme it is a criminal offence under section 18(2) of the Energy Act 1976.

8.4.6 Each essential user will be issued with an A4 logo that will consist of a blue / yellow background which is divided into 4 squares, in the bottom left hand corner will be the Essex Resilience Logo and in the bottom right hand corner will be the MSE logo and a unique identifiable number and letters system, in the centre will be the seal of Her Majesty's Government. The Temporary Logo will be printed in color and ideally laminated to maintain longevity.
8.4.7 The space on the reverse of the Temporary Logo is for organizational or other information and an example appears below.

The person on whose vehicle this “Temporary Logo” is displayed is employed by or otherwise authorised by Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Hospital Trust and provides an “Essential Service” as defined within the Essex local resilience Forum procedures for priority Users of Fuel. To obtain fuel the person will produce their ID staff Card along with this Temporary Logo.
The Temporary Logo is to be used only by the authorised person to whom it is issued and for the sole purpose of acquiring fuel for the delivery of “essential
services” during the period the National Emergency Plan for Fuel is in force. It must be produced at Designated Filling Stations, together with the person's Staff ID Card.
The Temporary Logo is not transferable and must be kept secure and out of sight of casual observers when not in use. Its loss must be reported immediately to the person's line manager.
Any use of this Temporary Logo to secure fuel by a person not employed as above may render the user liable to disciplinary action, arrest and prosecution.
All other staff will not be designated as essential users, and will receive fuel in line with the National Fuel Plan.
8.4.8 In the event of the TLS being implemented:
Managers will identify essential car users who will need a temporary logo for the period of the fuel disruption

Temporary Logo's (Appendix 1) will be issued following approval by the Fuel Incident Team by the Emergency Planning Liaison Officer for staff who may require fuel in order to fulfil their duties in the organisation
A Temporary Logo will be issued to the staff member for the purpose of one visit to the designated fuel station

The Temporary Logo will be returned to the Head of Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response after fuel has been obtained & recipient's shift has ended along with a copy of the receipt from the filling station verifying the amount of fuel obtained
A log will be maintained each time a Temporary Logo is used and the circumstances as to why it was required
The copy of the filling station receipt will be kept with the log

8.4.9 In order to obtain fuel, users of Temporary Logos will be required to produce the logo along with their Staff ID at the point of sale or kiosk at a Designated Filling Station (DFS). Once the fuel retailer is satisfied that they are a legitimate user they will turn on the pumps.

8.4.10 The MSE will be asked to provide a central telephone contact number as a point of reference for both staff and DFSs. Where there is doubt about a Temporary Logo or Staff ID, the DFS operator will make enquiries using this number as will staff with the Temporary Logo should the DFS operator refuses
to allow them fuel.
It must be remembered that abuse of this scheme is an offence and could lead to prosecution.
Essential car users

8.5.1 In order to maintain the Trust's core function within a fuel shortage, the Trust must decide what its priority functions are and who requires fuel to deliver them. It is the responsibility of Divisional General Managers to undertake this task and authorise collection of a Temporary Logo to personnel. Utilising Department of Health Guidelines, prioritisation must be given to, in order of priority:
Activities to reduce mortality, morbidity and significant progression of disease
Activities that will alleviate human suffering, including palliative care
Activities that meet any legal obligations, such as those contained in The Children Act 2004, Mental Health Act 2007 and others
All other emergency clinical and social services
All other routine clinical and social services
All other functions and services

8.5.2 The term only applies to services delivered away from a fixed location i.e. if a person or service is premises based for normal daily work then the term does not apply. In order to meet the requirements of the essential service definition, people or services must need to deliver external visits to provide a service or function. An individual being classed as an “essential car user” within any organization does not necessarily mean that they provide an essential service. Guidance from DECC suggests that when considering whether a service is essential the question to be asked “Is this service delivered on Christmas Day?”
Designated filling stations

8.6.1 The activation of designated filling stations will enable fuel supplies to be available to nominated priority temporary logo holders. Fuel suppliers will give priority to these stations to maintain availability as far as possible for priority users. he department of Energy and Climate Change will publish a list of Designated Filling Stations, this information will be cascaded to the Emergency Planning Liaison Officer by NHS England, this in turn will be passed on to those staff identified as requiring a temporary logo.
Resources and suppliers

8.7.1 A commercial scheme also exists to enable national supply chains to access fuel to continue the bulk delivery of pharmaceuticals and consumables to the Trust. It is the Trust's responsibility during shortage to ensure that they engage with suppliers to receive assurance of the delivery of essential supplies. Business Continuity plans should be written in preparation for suppliers being unable to provide restock by
managers in:
Procurement
Pharmacy
Nom-clinical support services
Any other appropriate service manager
Workforce issues

8.8.1 As per the Trust Attendance Management Policy all Trust employees have a responsibility to attend for work and perform the duties of their post unless they have an authorised absence, for example, sickness absence, parental leave or annual leave. Employees should not attend work if they are unwell or unfit, if in doing so they would affect their health and the health of others.

8.8.2 This responsibility does not change during fuel shortages. Where staff are unable to attend work due to fuel shortage impacts, such as inability to access fuel or school closures, the usual procedures for absence should be followed, with managers using their discretion on a case by case basis. Where managers have concerns they should take advise from a member of the HR team.

8.8.3 During a severe fuel disruption flexibility with regards to working patterns will be needed. Ward/Departmental Heads and Managers will need to be sensitive to problems staff will have regarding punctuality due to transport arrangements. Manager's may at their discretion look at altering staff start or finish times. Additionally where staff are unable to attend the site, they may be asked to work at other nearby healthcare facilities, particularly during times of national emergency.

8.8.4 Temporary changes to shift patterns may be required during the duration of the fuel disruption. Increasing the length of the working day and reducing the number of days worked is an effective way of reducing fuel consumption for staff. Such shift patterns are already in use in some clinical areas around the organisation.

8.8.5 Non-clinical staff, staff in some administration functions such as personnel, IT, finance and some management staff may be able to work from home during a severe fuel disruption, however sufficient on site cover should be maintained. Information services may be required to provide increased support through provision of laptops, offsite access for email (VPNs) etc.
8.8.6 Managers and staff to ascertain effectiveness and merit of working from home in exceptional circumstances.
Demand calming

8.9.1 In the event of the NEP-F being implemented measures designated to reduce public consumption of fuel will be put in place. The public will be encouraged to limit car usage and to maximise fuel efficiency. Public transport, cycling and walking will be promoted.
8.9.2 Employers will be encouraged to instigate:
A communications strategy to provide guidance to staff
Working from home
Use of alternative work locations closer to home
Flexible
Working hours
Extended hours over fewer days to reduce the number of journeys made
Car sharing schemes
Promotion of public transport, cycling, walking (especially staff who live within 3 miles of their place of work)
Reduction / cancellation of non-clinical services
Cancellation of non- essential meetings and training
Increased use of video / teleconferencing facilities
Temporary accommodation at or close to work locations
Car sharing

8.10.1 During a major fuel disruption the Trust will encourage staff to share the use of a car by those whom travel to work from similar areas and have similar duty Rota's. Staff having problems travelling to work are to contact their Manager at the earliest opportunity who may assist in making arrangements to match them up with another member of staff living in the same area working on the same day. A degree of flexibility on start and finish times will be needed for this. Each car share should be logged by the Manager or Ward/Departmental Head to ensure staff safety.
Flexible shifts and working from home

8.11.1 During a severe fuel disruption flexibility with regards to working patterns will be needed. Ward/Departmental Heads and Managers will need to be sensitive to problems staff will have regarding punctuality due to transport arrangements.

8.11.2 Temporary changes to shift patterns may be required during the duration of the fuel disruption. Increasing the length of the working day and reducing the number of days worked is an effective way of reducing fuel consumption for staff. Such shift patterns are already in use in some clinical areas around the organisation.

8.11.3 Non-clinical staff, staff in some administration functions such as personnel, IT, finance and some management staff may be able to work from home during a severe fuel disruption, however sufficient on site cover should be maintained. Information services may be required to provide increased support through provision of laptops, offsite access for email (VPNs) etc.
8.11.4 In exceptional circumstances, managers and staff to ascertain effectiveness and merit of working from home.
Accommodation

8.12.1 The hospital is able to provide a small amount of accommodation on site but this will depend on the current occupancy. In exceptional circumstances the use of local travel lodges and hotels may need to be considered.
8.12.2 Staff who may benefit from accommodation may include:
On-call staff
Staff working consecutive days that have to travel a long distance to work, and
Clinical staff working consecutive late/early shifts.
Human resources
8.13.1 During a prolonged fuel shortage increased pressures on staffing numbers are inevitable. Workforce mapping and key skills analysis should be undertaken by each Department / Ward / Area to:
Facilitate the redeployment of staff around the Trust
Identify those members of staff that could work from home
Identify those members of staff that could work at an alternative site.
8.13.2 These issues to be considered and included within departmental business continuity plans.
Communication
External communications

In the event of any disruption to fuel supply or distribution, the Trust will have to report its fuel requirements over a given period in order to maintain the delivery of healthcare. Therefore, the Trust needs to be prepared to monitor and declare usage to regional resilience structures and Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs). Whilst the exact reporting route is being developed further by DECC, Cabinet Office and Department of Health, the Trust should continue to provide exception reporting to CCGs via the normal NHS reporting mechanisms and daily situation reports (SITREPS).
Communication with Staff

9.2.1 Care needs to be taken in key messages that the MSE disseminate to staff during a disruption or potential disruption in fuel supply. Inaccurate and inappropriate messages to MSE staff may have the effect of fueling rumors and causing panic buying. Panic buying of fuel may either create a problem where there was not one or exacerbate an existing problem.

9.2.2 In the event of a fuel disruption General Managers / Associate General Managers, and heads of Service will be briefed through the Director lead via the Fuel Incident Team. They will be advised on actions that must be taken and given any central messages received by the MSE.
9.2.3 It is important that any information that the Trust disseminates is in line with that of the government in order to maintain consistency and public confidence.
All Communication will be agreed with and coordinated vis the Fuel Incident Team
Messages to staff will be given through their line managers
Any correspondence with the media must be conducted through the MSE Communications Departments
A document containing demand calming measures will be posted on the Emergency Planning Intranet Page (Hub) for staff to read.
Demand calming measures
9.3.1  The following is a list of key messages which could be communicated to staff to reduce their fuel consumption:

Don't use a car if you really don't need to: If you live close to your destination do you really need to drive? If you live one or two miles from work or school, why not walk or ride a bike? Taking a bus or train is also a fuel-efficient alternative to driving alone. Consider alternating the driving with others whose children attend the same school or activities as your children do. As for commuting to and from work, why not offer to share a ride with another colleague living nearby or a neighbour working close to you? Drive your car only when necessary. Don't use it for those 'around the corner' trips, walk instead. Don't make two trips when one will do. Combine errands in a single trip.

Maintain your car properly: A poorly tuned engine can increase fuel consumption by up to 50%. By properly maintaining your car and by following the recommended maintenance schedule in your owner's manual you can maximise fuel efficiency. With a well-tuned engine you will also minimise engine wear and tear.

Plan your journey: Sitting in traffic will reduce the vehicle's fuel economy. It is therefore better to plan ahead and avoid travelling at peak times when congestion is likely. Carefully plan your route in advance.

Don't carry unnecessary weight: A rooftop carrier provides additional baggage space and may allow you to meet all your driving needs with a smaller vehicle. However, a loaded rack can increase fuel consumption by as much as five per cent in motorway driving. Even the most streamlined empty rack will increase fuel consumption by about one per cent when it's not loaded. If the carrier is not permanently fixed to your vehicle, remove it when it is not needed.

Be a steady driver: Fuel can be saved by using a steady driving technique where the driver anticipates what is ahead and keeps as constant a speed as possible. In general, a one-unit increase in speed requires a three-unit increase in power consumption. It is therefore beneficial if a driver can avoid high speeds while at the same time maintaining the overall average speed. This can be achieved by anticipating what lies ahead on the road and by selecting the most suitable route.

Restrict your speed: For most fuel-efficient cruising do not exceed  miles per hour (DfT estimate). Most cars use about 10% less fuel when driven at 50mph rather than 62mph and a reduction in speed from 68mph to 50mph can reduce fuel consumption by 20%. The optimum speed for HGVs is also below 50mph and large vehicles can achieve similar savings in fuel consumption by reducing their speed to this level.

Don't idle: No matter how efficient your car, idling consumes fuel. One minute of idling uses up more fuel than restarting your engine. Turn off the ignition if you are waiting (it would also help to relieve air pollution).

Use electrics less: Car electrics impose an extra load on the engine, making it work harder and burn more fuel. Air conditioning can increase fuel consumption by up to ten percent in stop-go traffic. At motorway speeds, air conditioning increases fuel consumption by three to four per cent. Flow-through ventilation reduces the need to drive with air conditioning on or with windows open, both of which consume more fuel. A sun roof can reduce the need for air conditioning, but when the roof is open at motorway speeds, wind resistance is increased and greater fuel consumption will result.
Heating and stand-by power generation

Heating and hot water services would continue via available dual fuel. In the event of a main fuel supply disruption, heating and hot water services would be maintained from the reserve stocks of fuel oil held on site, these stocks would last for more than 4 days.
This is a permanent business continuity measure.
Business continuity

All departments should have clear and concise business continuity plans that detail service prioritisation and key actions in the event of a loss of utilities. These plans should be utilised during times of pressure on services as a result of a fuel shortage.

As with all challenges on business continuity there will be a period of post incident recovery. The main emphasis of this period is to return to normal working practices. It is envisaged that recovery from a fuel shortage would be relatively swift, at worst 10 days. Under the direction of the Fuel Incident Team services will be resumed in order of the priority in which they stand within the Trust as per business continuity plans.
Recovery to normal service provision

Recovery is defined as the procedure of rebuilding, restoring and rehabilitating the organisation as a whole post incident. In simpler terms it is replacing what has been lost or reduced and the rehabilitation of those affected e.g. staff that have been covering and maintaining the services during the disruption.

Recovery from a national fuel disruption may be a prolonged process depending on the length of the incident itself and the amount of disruption it causes to staff and services within the Trust. As well as regaining normal service delivery, recovery should be used as a tool to learn from the event which has occurred and develop more efficient ways of coping if the procedures used did not work as well as first thought. It is recommended that the Trust perform a staff debrief to ascertain lessons identified and make improvements to this plan and to individual Business Continuity Plans.

Recovery from a fuel disruption should begin at the earliest possible opportunity and this could run in unison with the Trust's response to the event. Recovery should continue until the disruption has totally stopped and the effects on the Trust have been rectified.

Recovery should work by firstly enabling the services which were scaled down to regain full capacity, followed by the services which were temporarily discontinued and then any other services which were affected in order for the Trust to be working at normal service delivery. This may take a longer time than the Trust's actual response time of the disruption itself.
The Fuel Incident Team will ensure the following actions have been completed:
Advise the Trust communications team to inform all staff of the end of the fuel   emergency
Reinstate services as required, communicating to Trust staff where appropriate
Advise that all temporary logos should be returned within one week to the Trusts Emergency Planning Liaison Officer
Complete a full audit of all issued MSE logos and inform LRF that all logos have
been returned.
12.5.1 At the start of the recovery process, it is vital that a clear recovery strategy is developed and agreed by the Fuel Incident team;
12.5.2 The recovery strategy will need to cover the following key objectives;
Ensure General Managers / Associate General Managers carry out an impact assessment and report to the Fuel incident team;
Ensure General Managers / Associate General Managers develop a recovery action plan in accordance with the Trust recovery strategy;
Ensure that an analysis of miles claimed through the temporary logo scheme is conducted.
12.5.3 The fuel incident team will carry out a full debrief of the emergency to incorporate:
What elements of the response went well;
What are areas for development;
Any other comments.

12.5.4 A full debrief report including recommendations will be produced by the Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response team and presented to the Board by the Head of Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response.
Monitoring and audit
13.1 Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Emergency Preparedness and Business Continuity Steering Committee which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Emergency Preparedness and Business Continuity Steering Committee of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 10)

Appendix 6: Temporary LOGO scheme guidance

This Temporary Logo has been issued to you to enable you to access the Temporary Logo Scheme (TLS) as a driver of a non-logoed vehicle to enable the essential health and critical life-saving services provided by or on behalf of Local Authorities, Health Authorities and Local Responders to continue. Temporary Logos will only be issued within working hours.
Only the person to whom this document has been issued is entitled to use it to obtain fuel at a Designated Filling Station (DFS).
Abuse of this Scheme is a criminal offence under section 18(2) of the Energy Act 1976 and offenders may be prosecuted.
A list of the local DFS is available by contacting the resilience team.

In order to obtain fuel, users of temporary logos must produce this document along with their (photographic) Staff ID Badge at the point-of-sale or kiosk at the DFS. They should also ensure that they have a valid means of payment.

DFS operators will only allow access to fuel once they are content that a recognisable logo has been displayed (vehicle or temporary), ID and means of payment has been confirmed. Once the Fuel Retailer is content that they are a legitimate user they will then turn on the pumps.

Where there is doubt about a Temporary Logo or identification the DFS operator will contact the Hospital Incident Control Room on the number provided to them in advance. Temporary-Logo users may also use this number if the DFS operator has refused to allow them access to fuel.

Temporary-logo holders who need to re-fuel their vehicles at a DFS outside their LRF area must inform the area in advance to ensure that refueling problems are not encountered. Fuel purchased under the TLS should only be used by the named member of staff carrying out critical functions of the Authority. It should not be used for non- critical or domestic use. Fuel for non- critical or domestic use should be purchased under the Maximum Purchase Scheme (MPS) at (non-DFS) retail filling stations.
There is no maximum purchase when refueling under the TLS at a DFS. Users are also allowed to fill portable containers with fuel required for their work.
Any misuse of this document may not only give rise to a prosecution as detailed but also internal disciplinary action.
